stream_context.summary: Kaze integrates and refines a large number of new 3D models provided by graphics artist Biobak, including switches, enemies, and effects. The stream is a deep dive into the iterative process of asset implementation, debugging rendering and collision issues, and collaborative design refinement with the team via live chat.

development_findings.summary: Kaze deliberately avoids using bone-based animations for simple objects like switches, opting instead to use multiple distinct models for each animation state. He considers the bone implementation in the toolchain 'jank' and unreliable.
development_findings.quote: You're wasting minutes of my life having me implement a switch bone when they basically don't really work at all. Have you ever actually tried to do something like this with switch bones? It sucks. It doesn't work. Ever.

development_findings.summary: The team is using a new technique for textures requiring transparency, combining a standard color texture with a separate, higher-resolution alpha mask to achieve smooth, anti-aliased edges on the N64.
development_findings.quote: We now have much, much smoother edges here. And it looks so much better. It doesn't look crusty.

development_findings.summary: Performance is a constant concern. Kaze must carefully manage how textures are applied to models to ensure they can be batch rendered efficiently, as improper setup can lead to significant lag from redundant texture loading.
development_findings.quote: The problem with this is, if we have the feet like this, it's gonna load the top texture, load this texture and then load these textures separately. So if we do that, then we would have a lot more lag.

development_findings.summary: A major breakthrough occurred when Kaze discovered the NEMU emulator accurately replicates hardware crashes found on the N64, which will dramatically speed up the process of debugging low-level floating-point exceptions.
development_findings.quote: Wait, NEMU crashes here just like N64 would? That's crazy. I could probably debug a lot of N64 crashes in NEMU then. Oh my god, that is going to save me so much time.

development_findings.summary: There is a significant, unresolved bug affecting underwater physics, causing raycasting issues and instant death in some levels, as well as strange wall collision behavior.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds strong opinions on software development, believing concepts like private variables are useless abstractions that have no basis in how a processor actually functions.
context_findings.quote: Private variables don't exist in C. That's like a delusion that C++ programmer streamed up. Private variables don't exist on the processor. Why is it a thing in your code?

context_findings.summary: Kaze analyzes popular content creators like MrBeast to understand principles of audience engagement, indicating a desire to grow his platform and apply those learnings.
context_findings.quote: I actually study MrBeast's videos like a fucking nerd. I look at them and be like, Oh, why do people like this? How can I implement this?

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong disdain for the original Mario 64 assets, which is the driving philosophy behind the team's effort to replace nearly every model in the game with custom creations.
context_findings.quote: Why you didn't use vanilla blue switch? Because it looks like dog shit? What? All the vanilla models are awful.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is aware of significant, annoying-to-fix bugs related to floating point exceptions that cause crashes on original N64 hardware, a key challenge for ensuring the game is stable.
context_findings.quote: I found out that a lot of the levels have floating point exceptions when you enter them right now on N64. Which is not going to be difficult to fix, but it's going to be annoying as fuck.

biobak.summary: Biobak is the primary contributor for this development session, having provided a large batch of updated 3D models for Kaze to implement, including switches, enemies, and effects.
biobak.quote: Oh my god, so many files. Alright. So we are going to import all of Biobak's remade models today.

biobak.summary: Biobak designed a new boss character, nicknamed 'Net Peanut', which Kaze praised as a 'genius' concept for its creative use of existing game textures like steel beams for its teeth.
biobak.quote: But the beams and teeth is genius. Biobak deserves a medal for that.

biobak.summary: Biobak actively participates in the stream chat, providing real-time feedback, technical explanations for his models, and offering to make immediate revisions based on in-game testing.

Biobak's new Goomba model, while visually an improvement, introduced technical challenges related to texture sharing and color-changing variants that require significant code changes to implement correctly.

zeina.summary: Zeina is actively working on character animations, having recently completed a new walk/run cycle for the Wiggler enemy.
zeina.quote: I think I finally got Wiggler's walk or run looking right.

key_stories.title: The Cap Switch Redesign
key_stories.summary: The team redesigned the classic cap switch, leading to a debate about the best way to animate it. Kaze's pragmatic decision to use multiple models instead of a complex but unreliable bone system resulted in a better, more stable feature and showcased his development priorities.
key_stories.challenge: The vanilla cap switches were considered ugly and needed a replacement that fit the game's new art style and had a satisfying press animation.
key_stories.process: Biobak provided a new model. Kaze and the team iterated on its lighting in real-time. For the animation, Kaze vehemently rejected using the toolchain's 'jank' bone system and instead created several distinct in-between models. After implementing them and adding color variants, community member Lilaa pointed out a placement error, which Kaze immediately fixed.
key_stories.outcome: A new, visually superior cap switch was implemented using multiple models for its animation states. The final result is more reliable and faster to implement than a bone-based solution, reflecting Kaze's pragmatic development philosophy.
key_stories.key_quote: You're wasting minutes of my life having me implement a switch bone when they basically don't really work at all... It sucks. It doesn't work. Ever.

key_stories.title: The Accidental Debugging Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: A frustrating visual bug on a new effect led to a tedious debugging session. While fixing the bug, Kaze made a major breakthrough discovery: he could use a specific emulator to replicate and debug low-level hardware crashes, a finding that will save him immense time and effort.
key_stories.challenge: A new ground pound star effect, designed by Biobak, was rendering as a corrupted white circle in-game instead of the intended blue starburst, and the cause was unknown.
key_stories.process: Kaze suspected a bug in the renderer or a graphics plugin setting. He tested the effect on a different emulator (NEMU) to isolate the problem. While the bug persisted, he realized NEMU was accurately replicating hardware crashes. After failing to find the specific setting causing the issue, Kaze deleted the graphics combiner and recreated it, which solved the problem.
key_stories.outcome: The visual glitch was fixed by rebuilding the graphics combiner from scratch. More importantly, the debugging process led Kaze to discover that the NEMU emulator could replicate low-level hardware crashes, providing a powerful new tool that will significantly accelerate future debugging.
key_stories.key_quote: Wait, NEMU crashes here just like N64 would? That's crazy. I could probably debug a lot of N64 crashes in NEMU then. Oh my god, that is going to save me so much time.
